messages.content: Hi! I'm planning a trip to Japan next spring and I could use some help organizing everything. We have about three weeks and want to see as much as possible - Tokyo, Kyoto, Osaka, Hiroshima, and maybe some rural areas. What would you recommend for a first-time visitor?

That's exciting! Japan in spring is beautiful, especially for cherry blossom season. For three weeks you can cover a lot. I'd suggest: Tokyo 5-6 days, Kyoto 5-6 days with day trips to Nara and Arashiyama, Osaka 2-3 days, Hiroshima 1-2 days with Miyajima. For rural areas, consider Takayama, Kanazawa, or the Japan Alps. The key is balancing cities with some slower-paced regions. What are your main interests - culture, food, nature, or a mix?

We're really into traditional culture - temples, tea ceremonies, traditional crafts. Also big foodies so local cuisine is important. My spouse has a gluten intolerance so we need to be careful. We prefer quieter accommodations when possible, not big chain hotels. We don't speak Japanese - will that be a problem?

Great mix! For traditional culture: Kyoto is perfect - Gion, Kiyomizu-dera, Fushimi Inari. Tea ceremonies can be booked in Kyoto. For crafts: Kanazawa has gold leaf, Kyoto has textiles. For food: Tokyo and Osaka are incredible. Gluten-free is improving - carry a Japanese allergy card, many restaurants in tourist areas have options. Language: tourist areas have basic English; Google Translate works well. For accommodations: consider ryokans in Kyoto - traditional, quiet, often with kaiseki dinners. I'll factor all this into a detailed itinerary.

Perfect. So let's start with the itinerary. We're arriving in Tokyo on March 20th and flying out from Tokyo on April 8th. We want 5 days Tokyo, 6 days Kyoto with day trips, 3 days Osaka, 2 days Hiroshima. That leaves a few days - maybe for Takayama or Kanazawa? And we're thinking of getting a JR Pass for the shinkansen.

That timeline works well - March 20 to April 8 captures cherry blossom season. Draft: Tokyo March 20-24, Kyoto March 25-30 (Nara March 28, Arashiyama March 29), Osaka March 31-April 2, Hiroshima April 3-4, then Takayama or Kanazawa April 5-6, back to Tokyo April 7 for your flight. JR Pass: for Tokyo-Kyoto-Osaka-Hiroshima-Takayama-Tokyo, a 14-day pass likely pays off. The round-trip alone is expensive. Book Shinkansen seats in advance for cherry blossom season.

Should we get the 7-day or 14-day JR Pass? I've read the 14-day is only worth it if you do a lot of long-distance travel. We're doing Tokyo-Kyoto-Osaka-Hiroshima-Kanazawa-Tokyo. Also, can we use the JR Pass for local trains in Tokyo and Kyoto or just the shinkansen?

For your route, the 14-day pass is worth it - Tokyo to Kyoto alone is expensive, plus Kyoto-Osaka-Hiroshima-Kanazawa-Tokyo adds up. The JR Pass covers: all JR trains including Shinkansen, JR local lines in Tokyo (Yamanote, Chuo, etc.), JR lines in Kyoto (to Nara, etc.), and most long-distance JR trains. It does NOT cover subways (Tokyo Metro, Toei, Kyoto subway) or private lines. So you'll use a mix - JR where possible, buy separate tickets for non-JR. The 14-day pass usually breaks even around 2-3 long trips.

Got it. For accommodations - we've booked a ryokan in Gion for one night. Any other areas you'd recommend for hotels? We're looking at Asakusa in Tokyo for the traditional feel, and maybe Namba in Osaka for the food scene. For Kyoto we have the ryokan but need 5 more nights - Higashiyama or near Kyoto Station?

Asakusa is great for Tokyo - traditional, Senso-ji temple nearby, good connections. Namba in Osaka is perfect - food, nightlife, Dotonbori. For Kyoto: Higashiyama if you want walkable temples and atmosphere; near Kyoto Station if you prefer convenience for day trips. Higashiyama is more atmospheric but hills; Station area is flat and central. I'd lean Higashiyama for 2-3 nights then Station for the rest if you're doing multiple day trips. Book early - spring is peak season.

We'll go with Higashiyama. Now for restaurants - can you suggest must-try foods in each city? We want sushi, ramen, tempura, okonomiyaki, takoyaki, kaiseki. For gluten-free: I've heard sushi is usually safe, and tamari soy sauce is gluten-free. What about ramen and okonomiyaki? Are there gluten-free options?

Tokyo: sushi at Tsukiji outer market or dedicated sushi-ya; tempura at specialized shops; ramen - try shoyu, miso, tonkotsu. Kyoto: kaiseki (you'll get this at ryokan), yudofu, matcha sweets. Osaka: okonomiyaki and takoyaki are musts. For gluten: sushi (rice, fish) is usually safe - request tamari. Ramen is wheat-based; some shops offer gluten-free or rice noodles - research ahead. Okonomiyaki uses flour - harder; a few places in Tokyo/Kyoto have gluten-free versions. Tokyo: Ain Soph, Gluten-Free T's Kitchen. Kyoto: Kyoto Gluten-Free Cafe. Always show your allergy card and confirm.

We'll look those up. What about cash vs card? I've heard Japan is still quite cash-heavy. Should we get yen before we leave or use ATMs there? And what about pocket WiFi vs SIM card - we'll need data for maps and translation. We have unlocked phones.

Cash: Japan is moving toward cards but many small restaurants, temples, and markets are cash-only. 7-Eleven and Japan Post ATMs accept foreign cards - withdraw at airport or any conbini. I'd get maybe $200 equivalent at airport, then use ATMs as needed. Cards work in hotels, department stores, many city restaurants. SIM vs WiFi: SIM is simpler for phones; pocket WiFi good if you have tablets/laptops. Both available at airport. Book online for better prices. eSIM is also an option if your phone supports it.

We'll go with SIM. For the shinkansen - should we book seats in advance or can we get unreserved? I've heard during cherry blossom season trains can be full. Also, what's the best way to get from Narita to Tokyo? We're landing around 6pm and staying in Asakusa.

Shinkansen: during peak season, reserved is safer. You can book at any JR office once in Japan - no need to book before arrival. Unreserved works but you might stand. For Narita to Asakusa: Keisei Skyliner to Ueno (41 min), then Ginza line to Asakusa. Cheaper and faster than Narita Express for your destination. Book Skyliner online for discount. With 6pm landing you'll clear customs by 7-7:30pm - trains run until later. Last Skyliner is around 10pm.

Perfect. One more thing - temple and onsen etiquette. We want to be respectful. For temples: do we pay to enter? What's the purification ritual? For onsens: we've never done public baths. Separate genders? What do we bring? My spouse has a small tattoo - is that an issue?

Temples: most have small fee (300-600 yen). Temizuya: dipper in right hand, pour over left, switch and pour over right, pour into left hand and rinse mouth, tilt dipper to rinse handle. Main hall: toss coin (5 yen is lucky), bow twice, clap twice, bow once. Onsen: usually gender-separated. Wash thoroughly at washing station before entering. No soap in bath. No swimsuits. Small towel on head, not in water. Tattoos: some places prohibit; many now allow or have private baths. Check your ryokan. They provide soap, shampoo, towels.

We'll practice the temple ritual. Any apps you'd recommend? We have Google Maps and Translate. What about for transit, restaurants, or last-minute bookings? Also, do we need a power adapter - we're from the US?

Apps: Google Maps works well for transit. Tabelog for restaurants. JapanTravel by Navitime for transit details. For power: Japan uses 100V, US 120V - close enough. Most electronics are 100-240V. Japan uses Type A plugs (same as US) so you may need nothing. Check your devices. Bring a power strip - hotel outlets can be limited. For bookings: most things you can do on the fly; popular restaurants might need advance reservation.

Thanks! We're thinking of buying a kimono or yukata as a souvenir. Where's best? Kyoto's Nishijin district? We're okay spending for quality - maybe $200-300. Also, any other souvenirs you'd recommend? We want to avoid the typical tourist junk.

Kyoto Nishijin is ideal for textiles. Shops like Hosoo for high-end. Used kimono shops in Gion for authentic pieces. For $200-300 you can get a nice yukata or a used silk kimono. Other souvenirs: Japanese knives (Tokyo), pottery (Kyoto, Bizen), lacquerware, quality green tea, artisan crafts from Takayama or Kanazawa. Avoid the 100-yen shop stuff at tourist spots. Look for small galleries and craft shops in quieter neighborhoods.

We'll check out Nishijin. Final question - travel insurance. Is it worth it for Japan? Any specific coverage we should look for? We're healthy but you never know. Also, any common mistakes first-timers make that we should avoid?

Travel insurance: recommended. Japan has excellent healthcare but it's expensive for visitors. Look for: medical coverage, evacuation, trip cancellation. World Nomads and SafetyWing are popular. Common mistakes: overpacking the itinerary - build in rest. Missing last trains (they stop around midnight). Forgetting places close Mon/Tue. No backup if blossoms are early/late. Not making restaurant reservations for popular spots. Not carrying cash. Rushing - Japan rewards slow exploration. And at ryokans: shoes off, facing outward when you leave. Enjoy your trip!

One more thing - we want to visit a few specific temples. Besides Kiyomizu-dera and Fushimi Inari in Kyoto, what others would you recommend? We're interested in Zen gardens and peaceful atmosphere. Also, do we need to book temple visits in advance or can we just show up?

For Zen gardens: Ryoan-ji in Kyoto has the famous rock garden. Daitoku-ji temple complex has several sub-temples with gardens. In Tokyo, Senso-ji in Asakusa is a must. For peace: Kinkaku-ji (Golden Pavilion) is stunning. Most temples don't require advance booking - just show up during opening hours. Some smaller temples or special viewings might need reservation. Kiyomizu-dera and Fushimi Inari can get crowded - go early morning. Ryoan-ji is usually quieter. Bring cash for entrance fees (300-600 yen typically).

We'll aim for early mornings. What about the Tokyo food scene - any specific neighborhoods or streets we shouldn't miss? We've heard about Tsukiji, but what about smaller local spots? We want a mix of tourist highlights and authentic local experiences.

Tsukiji outer market is great for breakfast sushi and street food. For local spots: Yanaka has old Tokyo atmosphere and small eateries. Shibuya and Shinjuku have endless options - try a ramen shop in a basement or a standing sushi bar. Ueno has good casual food. For something different: Yurakucho under the tracks has classic izakayas. Kagurazaka has a mix of French and Japanese. Avoid only eating in Ginza - expensive and touristy. Wander side streets; some of the best meals are in unmarked spots. Tabelog app helps find highly-rated local places.

Perfect. Last question - we're considering a day trip from Tokyo to Nikko or Kamakura. Which would you recommend for a first visit? We have one spare day. We like history and nature, and we're okay with a longer train ride if it's worth it.

Both are great. Nikko: longer ride (2 hours from Tokyo), stunning Toshogu Shrine, beautiful nature, Kegon Falls. More of a full day. Kamakura: shorter (1 hour), Great Buddha, temple trail, beach. Easier day. For history and grandeur: Nikko. For variety and easier pace: Kamakura. If you want one recommendation: Nikko is more spectacular and unique. Kamakura is lovely but similar vibe to some Kyoto temples. Either way you can't go wrong. Book the limited express to Nikko for a smoother ride.

constraints: language barrier due to not speaking Japanese
interests: food, especially sushi, ramen, tempura, okonomiyaki, takoyaki, kaiseki

key_facts: spring in Japan for cherry blossoms
itinerary: Tokyo 5-6 days, Kyoto 6 days with day trips, Osaka 3 days, Hiroshima 2 days, rural areas for a few days
14-day JR Pass recommended due to multiple long-distance travels
ryokans in Gion and Higashiyama as preferred accommodations
must-try foods: sushi, ramen (shoyu, miso, tonkotsu), okonomiyaki, takoyaki, kaiseki
decisions: 5 days Tokyo, 6 days Kyoto with day trips, 3 days Osaka, 2 days Hiroshima, few days for Takayama or Kanazawa
14-day JR Pass for travel between cities
Ryokan in Gion and Higashiyama as accommodations
Nishijin district for souvenirs like kimono or yukata
Google Maps and Tabelog app recommendations for navigation and restaurant bookings
open_questions: Specific temples to visit beyond Kiyomizu-dera, Fushimi Inari in Kyoto
Detailed restaurant recommendations within specific neighborhoods
Additional souvenirs besides kimono or yukata
Travel insurance details and specific coverage needed
todos: Book ryokans in Gion and Higashiyama
Research gluten-free options for ramen and okonomiyaki
Plan travel to Nikko or Kamakura day trip
Confirm restaurant reservations for popular spots
Prepare allergy cards and research local payment methods
